instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD1: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD1? PP2V5_NAND_SSD1 is a power rail that powers the soldered on SSDs.
definitions.I2C_PWR_SCL: What is I2C_PWR_SCL? I2C_PWR_SCL is the clock line of the SMBUS data line between the system management controller(SMC), battery, ISL9240 battery charging chip, and power management unit(PMU). This line is necessary for the machine to communicate with the battery, see the battery, and use the battery. When this line is malfunctioning or shorted to ground, the machine will have an X icon over the battery and not run off the battery. .
definitions.I2C_PWR_SDA: What is I2C_PWR_SDA? I2C_PWR_SDA is the SMBUS data line between the system management controller(SMC), battery, ISL9240 battery charging chip, and power management unit(PMU). This line is necessary for the machine to communicate with the battery, see the battery, and use the battery. When this line is malfunctioning or shorted to ground, the machine will have an X icon over the battery and not run off the battery. .
definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message:
I have a 2019 16" MBP (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-5) that will not power on. 20V 0A. T2 is not booting and is not recognized by Configurator 2 in normal or jumpered DFU mode. I strongly suspect a short, but cannot find one.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLP2R</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 1.1V
PP0V8SLPS2R - 0.8V

PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE - present
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - present
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - present
<SIGNAL>PMU_SYS_ALIVE</SIGNAL> - present
<SIGNAL>PMU_COLD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - present
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> - present

<SIGNAL>I2C_PWR_SCL</SIGNAL> - not short
<SIGNAL>I2C_PWR_SDA</SIGNAL> - not short
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> - not short
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> - not short

All power attempts done with battery and BMU cable connected. Both were replaced by Apple recently. I also replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and checked all surrounding resistors and caps. I'm fearing the T2 itself is bad. Have I missed anything? Any help appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Any history available?
Check <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 84913, member: 682"]
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Any history available?
Check <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> level.
[/QUOTE]
Thank you! I have been a lurker for several years just reading all that I can, but I'm starting to have newer machines that elude me.

No history for this computer. Under the scope when I got it it looked very clean, no traces of corrosion anywhere that I could see.

<SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> is 0V without a short. Inputs to <CHIP>U6940</CHIP> are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message:
PMU reset is good, so must be other problem.

Looks like T2 internal issue.
The machine should be recognized in DFU, if all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are present.
Did you follow all the steps in DFU tutorial?
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

BTW, write directly into reply box, instead of clicking Reply button.
I don't see any reason to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message:
True. Bad habit!

I have tried DFU steps many times. Will it enter DFU mode even if NO current is being drawn? Does the battery have to be connected, and BMU cable?

Is the keyboard bad? Is the T2 itself bad? Can this be replaced, or is that foolish?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message:
No battery needed for DFU.
5V on USB-C input is enough.

The board can be forced into DFU without keyboard.
Just tie <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message: Yes, I've jumpered it (first post), but it makes no difference.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 85007, member: 682"]
Then T2 fails...
[/QUOTE]
This is a [I]very [/I]long shot--bear with me--I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that I believe the T2 is fine on. Can I replace the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>'s T2 with the one from the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>? Ignoring the complexity of the BGA work--would it work?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message: This is a [I]very [/I]long shot--bear with me--I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that I believe the T2 is fine on. threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message:
Very likely not.
We still expect someone to do such thing and let feedback on the forum.
However, need to take T2 from same model donot board.
Also, keep in mind, chip ID is baked into T2; no way to change it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power (20V, 0A)
threads.message:
I hate T2..
Help very much appreciated though, thank you.
